item.title: Alissa add a quote by William S. Burroughs
item.description: "Confusion hath fuck his masterpiece." -- William S. Burroughs

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "You never know what worse luck your bad luck has saved you from." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Federico García Lorca
item.description: "To burn with desire and keep quiet about it is the greatest punishment we can bring on ourselves." -- Federico García Lorca

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Theodore Roethke
item.description: "Those who are willing to be vulnerable move among mysteries." -- Theodore Roethke

item.title: Alissa add a quote by J.R.R. Tolkien
item.description: "All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us." -- J.R.R. Tolkien

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Thomas Hardy
item.description: "Though a good deal is too strange to be believed, nothing is too strange to have happened." -- Thomas Hardy

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Agatha Christie
item.description: "The impossible could not have happened, therefore the impossible must be possible in spite of appearances." -- Agatha Christie

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "And I asked myself about the present: how wide it was, how deep it was, how much was mine to keep." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Euripides
item.description: "Talk sense to a fool and he calls you foolish." -- Euripides

item.title: Alissa add a quote by William Blake
item.description: "To see a World in a Grain of Sand And a Heaven in a Wild Flower, Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand And Eternity in an hour." -- William Blake

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "If you don't feel that you are possibly on the edge of humiliating yourself, of losing control of the whole thing, then probably what you are doing isn't very vital." -- John Irving

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Edith Wharton
item.description: "My little old dog a heart-beat at my feet" -- Edith Wharton

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Muir
item.description: "When one tugs at a single thing in nature, he finds it attached to the rest of the world." -- John Muir

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Philip K. Dick
item.description: "It is sometimes an appropriate response to reality to go insane." -- Philip K. Dick

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Walter Kirn
item.description: "Art, art of any kind, shows that folks are trying." -- Walter Kirn

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Richard P. Feynman
item.description: "Nobody ever figures out what life is all about, and it doesn't matter. Explore the world. Nearly everything is really interesting if you go into it deeply enough." -- Richard P. Feynman

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Anderson Cooper
item.description: "The farther you go...the harder it is to return. The world has many edges and it's easy to fall off." -- Anderson Cooper

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Charles Eames
item.description: "Eventually everything connects - people, ideas, objects. The quality of the connections is the key to quality per se." -- Charles Eames

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "Laughter and tears are both responses to frustration and exhaustion. I myself prefer to laugh, since there is less cleaning do to do afterward." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "People only ask questions when they're ready to hear the answers." -- John Irving

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Lorraine Hansberry
item.description: "The thing that makes you exceptional, if you are at all, is inevitably that which must also make you lonely." -- Lorraine Hansberry

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Theodore Roethke
item.description:
"<b>The Waking</b>
I wake to sleep, and take my waking slow. I feel my fate in what I cannot fear. I learn by going where I have to go.
We think by feeling. What is there to know? I hear my being dance from ear to ear. I wake to sleep, and take my waking slow.
Of those so close beside me, which are you? God bless the Ground! I shall walk softly there, And learn by going where I have to go.
Light takes the Tree; but who can tell us how? The lowly worm climbs up a winding stair; I wake to sleep, and take my waking slow.
Great Nature has another thing to do To you and me, so take the lively air, And, lovely, learn by going where to go.
This shaking keeps me steady. I should know. What falls away is always. And is near. I wake to sleep, and take my waking slow. I learn by going where I have to go." -- Theodore Roethke

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Thomas Mann
item.description: "Solitude gives birth to the original in us, to beauty unfamiliar and perilous - to poetry. But also, it gives birth to the opposite: to the perverse, the illicit, the absurd." -- Thomas Mann

item.title: Alissa add a quote by Lewis Carroll
item.description: "Look after the senses and the sounds will look after themselves" -- Lewis Carroll

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "when however small a measure of jealousy is mixed with misunderstanding, there is always going to be trouble." -- John Irving

item.title: Alissa add a quote by T.H. White
item.description: "The bravest people are the ones who don’t mind looking like cowards." -- T.H. White

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "It is hard work and great art to make life not so serious." -- John Irving

item.title: Alissa add a quote by James Joyce
item.description: "Think you're escaping and run into yourself. Longest way round is the shortest way home." -- James Joyce

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "Crazy people made him crazy. It was as if he personally resented them giving into madness - in part, because he so frequently labored to behave sanely. When some people gave up the labor of sanity, or failed at it, Garp suspected them of not trying hard enough. " -- John Irving

item.title: Alissa add a quote by John Irving
item.description: "If you are careful,' Garp wrote, 'if you use good ingredients, and you don't take any shortcuts, then you can usually cook something very good. Sometimes it is the only worthwhile product you can salvage from a day; what you make to eat. With writing, I find, you can have all the right ingredients, give plenty of time and care, and still get nothing. Also true of love. Cooking, therefore, can keep a person who tries hard sane." -- John Irving
